entry.et: Middle English dippen, from Old English dyppan; akin to Old High German tupfen to wash, Lithuanian dubus deep

def.dt: :to plunge or immerse momentarily or partially under the surface (as of a liquid) so as to moisten, cool, or coat dip candles
:to thrust in a way to suggest immersion
:to immerse (as a sheep or dog) in an antiseptic or parasiticidal solution
:to lift a portion of by reaching below the surface with something shaped to hold liquid :ladle
:to take a portion of (snuff)
:involve
:mortgage
:to lower and then raise again dip a flag in salute
:dim 2
:to plunge into a liquid and quickly emerge
:to immerse something into a processing liquid or finishing material
:to suddenly drop down or out of sight
:to drop suddenly before climbing
:to decline or decrease moderately and usually temporarily prices dipped
:to lower the body momentarily especially as part of an athletic or dancing motion
:to withdraw a part of the contents of something by or as if by reaching down inside it used with into dipped into his pocket for change dipped into the family's savings
:to examine or read something casually or superficially used with into dip into a book
:to incline downward from the plane of the horizon
:an act of dipping
:a brief plunge into the water for sport or exercise a quick dip in the pool
:inclination downward:
:pitch
:a sharp downward course :drop a dip in popularity
:the angle that a stratum or similar geological feature makes with a horizontal plane
:the angle formed with the horizon by a magnetic needle free to rotate in the vertical plane
:hollow depression a dip in the road
:something obtained by or used in dipping a dip of ice cream a dip of snuff
:a sauce or soft mixture into which food may be dipped bean dip
:a liquid preparation for the dipping of something
:an insecticide or parasiticide for the dipping of animals a sheep dip
:pickpocket
:a stupid or unsophisticated person
dual in-line package; dual in-line packaging
diploma
:a bag net with a handle that is used especially to scoop fish from the water
:grab bag
:to swim in the nude
:a person who collects both a government pension and a government salary
